    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-groups.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,149 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about groups in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about groups in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about groups\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about groups.\n-\n-## Create a query to view groups\n-\n-When you select **Groups**, the **Usage Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of groups.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Groups** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Groups** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-    - **Group Type**: Select **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n-    - **Group Activity Status**: Select **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-    - **Tasks Type**: Select **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**\n-    - **Search**: Enter group name to find specific group.\n-1. To display the criteria you've selected, select **Apply**.\n-    - **Reset Filter**: Select to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Groups** table displays the results of your query:\n-\n-- **Group Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n-    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n-- A **Group Type** icon displays to the left of the group name to describe the type of group (**ED** (enterprise directory) or **Local**).\n-- The **Domain/Account** name.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **Users**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a group\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## View detailed information about a group\n-\n-1. Select the down arrow to the left of the **Group Name**.\n-\n-    The list of **Tasks** organized by **Unused** and **Used** displays.\n-\n-1. Select the arrow to the left of the group name to view details about the task.\n-1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n-1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n-1. The pane on the right displays a list of **Users**, **Policies** for **AWS** and **Roles** for **GCP or AZURE**, and **Tags**.\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-There are many filter options within the **Groups** screen, including filters by **Authorization System Type**, **Authorization System**, **Group Type**, **Group Activity Status**, and **Tasks Type**.\n-Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by group type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Group Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (enterprise directory), or **Local**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by group activity status\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Group Activity Status** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by tasks type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Tasks Type** dropdown, select the type of user: **All**, **High Risk Tasks**, or **Delete Tasks**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To view a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-- To view a list of members of the groups in your query, select **Export**, and then select  **Memberships**.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view active tasks, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-home.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,46 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management\n-description: How to use the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management to view details about users, groups, active resources, active tasks, access keys, and serverless functions.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information with the Analytics dashboard\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article provides a brief overview of the Analytics dashboard in Permissions Management, and the type of analytic information it provides for Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-\n-## Display the Analytics dashboard\n-\n-- From the Permissions Management home page, select the **Analytics** tab.\n-\n-    The **Analytics** dashboard displays detailed information about:\n-\n-    - **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage by users. For more information, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-\n-    - **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.  For more information, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n-\n-    - **Active Resources**: Tracks resources that have been used in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n-\n-    - **Active Tasks**: Tracks tasks that have been performed in the last 90 days.  For more information, see [View analytic information about active tasks](usage-analytics-active-tasks.md).\n-\n-    - **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.  For more information, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n-\n-    - **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions for AWS only.  For more information, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md).\n-\n-    System administrators can use this information to make decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage by users, see [View analytic information about users](usage-analytics-users.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members, see [View analytic information about groups](usage-analytics-groups.md).\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md)."
  },

    "sha": "324626745c5bf16eeccaac099c9df36d7dc6d494",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",
    "status": "removed",

    "deletions": 106,
    "changes": 106,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md",

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fusage-analytics-serverless-functions.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,106 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about serverless functions in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about serverless functions\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about serverless functions.\n-\n-## Create a query to view serverless functions\n-\n-When you select **Serverless Functions**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Serverless Functions** from the  dropdown list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Serverless Functions** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n-1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Serverless Functions** table displays the results of your query.\n-\n-- **Function Name**: Provides the name of the serverless function.\n-    - To view details about a serverless function, select the down arrow to the left of the function name.\n-- A **Function Type** icon displays to the left of the function name to describe the type of serverless function, for example **Lambda function**.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)**, and then select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a serverless function\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## View detailed information about a serverless function\n-\n-1. Select the down arrow to the left of the function name to display the following:\n-\n-    - A list of **Tasks** organized by **Used** and **Unused**.\n-    - **Versions**, if a version is available.\n-\n-1. Select the arrow to the left of the task name to view details about the task.\n-1. Select **Information** (**i**) to view when the task was last used.\n-1. From the **Tasks** dropdown, select **All Tasks**, **High Risk Tasks**, and **Delete Tasks**.\n-\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-You can filter the **Serverless Functions** results by **Authorization System Type** and **Authorization System**.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view active resources, see [View analytic information about active resources](usage-analytics-active-resources.md).\n-- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md)."
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,160 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View analytic information about users in Permissions Management\n-description: How to view analytic information about users in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View analytic information about users\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-The **Analytics** dashboard in Permissions Management collects detailed information, analyzes, reports on, and visualizes data about all identity types. System administrators can use the information to make informed decisions about granting permissions and reducing risk on unused permissions for:\n-\n-- **Users**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of various identities.\n-- **Groups**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the group and the group members.\n-- **Active Resources**: Tracks active resources (used in the last 90 days).\n-- **Active Tasks**: Tracks active tasks (performed in the last 90 days).\n-- **Access Keys**: Tracks the permission usage of access keys for a given user.\n-- **Serverless Functions**: Tracks assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions.\n-\n-This article describes how to view usage analytics about users.\n-\n-## Create a query to view users\n-\n-When you select **Users**, the **Analytics** dashboard provides a high-level overview of tasks used by various identities.\n-\n-1. On the main **Analytics** dashboard, select **Users** from the  drop-down list at the top of the screen.\n-\n-    The following components make up the **Users** dashboard:\n-\n-    - **Authorization System Type**: Select the authorization you want to use: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-    - **Authorization System**: Select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders***.\n-    - **Identity Type**: Select **All** identity types, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c** or **Resource**.\n-    - **Search**: Enter criteria to find specific tasks.\n-1. Select **Apply** to display the criteria you've selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## View the results of your query\n-\n-The **Identities** table displays the results of your query.\n-\n-- **Name**: Provides the name of the group.\n-    - To view details about the group, select the down arrow.\n-- The **Domain/Account** name.\n-- The **Permission Creep Index (PCI)**: Provides the following information:\n-    - **Index**: A numeric value assigned to the PCI.\n-    - **Since**: How many days the PCI value has been at the displayed level.\n-- **Tasks**: Displays the number of **Granted** and **Executed** tasks.\n-- **Resources**: The number of resources used.\n-- **User Groups**: The number of users who accessed the group.\n-- **Last Activity On**: The date the function was last accessed.\n--  The ellipses **(...)**: Select **Tags** to add a tag.\n-\n-    If you're using AWS, another selection is available from the ellipses menu: **Auto Remediate**. You can use this option to remediate your results automatically.\n-\n-## Add a tag to a user\n-\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Tags**.\n-1. From the **Select a Tag** dropdown, select a tag.\n-1. To create a custom tag select **New Custom Tag**, add a tag name, and then select **Create**.\n-1. In the **Value (Optional)** box, enter a value.\n-1. Select the ellipses **(...)** to select **Advanced Save** options, and then select **Save**.\n-1. To add the tag to the serverless function, select **Add Tag**.\n-\n-## Set the auto-remediate option (AWS only)\n-\n-- Select the ellipses **(...)** and select **Auto Remediate**.\n-\n-    A message displays to confirm that your remediation settings are automatically updated.\n-\n-## Apply filters to your query\n-\n-There are many filter options within the **Users** screen, including filters by **Authorization System**, **Identity Type**, and **Identity State**.\n-Filters can be applied in one, two, or all three categories depending on the type of information you're looking for.\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by authorization system\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select accounts from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity type\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Type**, select the type of user: **All**, **User**, **Role/App/Service a/c**, or **Resource**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity subtype\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Subtype**, select the type of user: **All**, **ED** (Enterprise Directory), **Local**, or **Cross Account**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity state\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity State**, select the type of user: **All**, **Active**, or **Inactive**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by identity filters\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Identity Type**, select: **Risky** or **Incl. in PCI Calculation Only**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-### Apply filters by task type\n-\n-You can filter user details by type of user, user role, app, or service used, or by resource.\n-\n-1. From the **Authorization System Type** dropdown, select the authorization system you want to use: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-1. From the **Authorization System** dropdown, select from a **List** of accounts and **Folders**.\n-1. From the **Task Type**, select the type of user: **All** or **High Risk Tasks**.\n-1. Select **Apply** to run your query and display the information you selected.\n-\n-    Select **Reset Filter** to discard your changes.\n-\n-\n-## Export the results of your query\n-\n-- To export a report of the results of your query as a comma-separated values (CSV) file, select **Export**, and then select **CSV**.\n-- To export the data in a detailed comma-separated values (CSV) file format, select **Export** and then select **CSV (Detailed)**.\n-- To export a report of user permissions, select **Export** and then select **Permissions**.\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To view the permission usage of access keys for a given user, see [View analytic information about access keys](usage-analytics-access-keys.md).\n-- To view assigned permissions and usage of the serverless functions, see [View analytic information about serverless functions](usage-analytics-serverless-functions.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "3cef9fc3c8b292d077c8659c78c714d0fc545795",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/whats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 101,
    "changes": 101,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fwhats-new-in-permissions-management.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,101 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-description: View the latest public preview and general availability of features in Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: whats-new\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# What's new in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article provides the latest Public Preview and General Availability information of features in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. \n-\n-## May 2024\n-\n-### General availability - Microsoft Entra Permissions Management integration for Microsoft Defender for Cloud\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-Deploying applications and infrastructure across multiple clouds has become the norm. Ensuring the security of cloud applications and infrastructure requires integrating identity and permission insights into the overall security strategy. This objective is achieved through the integration of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management with Microsoft Defender for Cloud. \n-\n-Permissions Management capabilities are available to integrate into the Defender for Cloud CSPM plan. Adding the capabilities of [Permissions Management to Defender for Cloud](permissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud.md) strengthens the prevention of security breaches that might occur due to excessive permissions or misconfigurations in the cloud environment. By continuously monitoring and managing cloud entitlements, Permissions Management helps to reduce the attack surface, detect potential threats, and maintain compliance with regulatory standards. These added features make Permissions Management an essential tool to integrate into the capabilities of Defender for Cloud for securing cloud-native applications and protecting sensitive data in the cloud. \n-\n-For instructions on how to enable Permissions Management in your Defender for Cloud environment, see [Enable Permissions Management in Microsoft Defender for Cloud](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2252561)\n-\n-\n-### General availability - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-Privileged Identity Management (PIM) for Groups in Microsoft Entra ID allows Permissions Management admins to grant users just-in-time membership and ownership of a security group or a Microsoft 365 group. Nested groups are also supported. For example, if a user is an active member of Group A, and Group A is an eligible member of Group B, the user can activate their membership in Group B. PIM provides a powerful mechanism to manage access and enhance security by granting just-in-time access to critical resources. \n-\n-Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership along with existing support for direct group membership. It also solves the challenge of having visibility into who has access to what resource with eligible and direct role assignments. This feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways and the potential impact on Permissions Creep Index (PCI). A complete list of RBAC role assignments is provisioned directly, via the group membership or by an eligible group member, and can be seen per identity under the Analytics tab. \n-\n-## March 2024\n-\n-### Public Preview - Support for PIM-enabled Groups \n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-As multiple customers embrace PIM for groups as a popular feature, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management adds the support to read the just-in-time membership impact on the eligible granted Azure RBAC permissions and Permissions Creep Index (PCI). The feature enables the complete visibility into RBAC permissions assigned to the identities in different ways.  \n- \n-In the Permissions Management console, admins can see the membership eligibility status as well as role eligibility status for Groups. For each identity, admins can get the visibility into the membership eligibility status as well as roles eligibility status. \n-\n-\n-## December 2023\n-\n-### General availability - Permissions Analytics Report PDF\n-\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                      \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management  \n-\n-The [Permissions Analytics Report (PAR)](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). \n-\n-The PAR PDF is one part of the overall reporting redesign effort led by the engineering team. As part of this feature release, customers can download all reports (system or custom) with no row limitations in CSV and XSLX formats. \n-\n-\n-## October 2023\n-\n-### Public preview - Permissions Analytics Report PDF for multiple authorization systems\n-\n-**Type:** Changed feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management            \n-\n-The Permissions Analytics Report (PAR) lists findings relating to permissions risks across identities and resources in Permissions Management. The PAR is an integral part of the risk assessment process where customers discover areas of highest risk in their cloud infrastructure. This report can be directly viewed in the Permissions Management UI, downloaded in Excel (XSLX) format, and exported as a PDF. The report is available for all supported cloud environments: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP).  \n-\n-The PAR PDF has a new design to enhance usability, align with the product UX redesign effort, and address various customer feature requests. [You can download the PAR PDF for up to 10 authorization systems](product-permissions-analytics-reports.md).\n-\n-### General availability - ServiceNow app for Permissions Management\n-\n-**Type:** New feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n-\n-The ServiceNow Application for Microsoft Entra Permissions Management enables users to request time-bound, on-demand permissions for multicloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP) through the ServiceNow portal. This integration aids organizations in enhancing their Zero Trust posture by enforcing the principle of least privilege for multicloud permissions. The ServiceNow app streamlines access permission requests within existing approval workflows.  \n-\n-Get the ServiceNow app in the [ServiceNow app store](https://store.servicenow.com/sn_appstore_store.do#!/store/application/24073ae31bfca9100e564082b24bcb56/1.0.1?referer=%2Fstore%2Fsearch%3Flistingtype%3Dallintegrations%25253Bancillary_app%25253Bcertified_apps%25253Bcontent%25253Bindustry_solution%25253Boem%25253Butility%25253Btemplate%25253Bgenerative_ai%25253Bsnow_solution%26q%3Dentra%2520permissions%2520management&sl=sh). \n-\n-### Public preview - Okta and AWS Identity Center identity provider integrations\n-\n-**Type:** New feature   \n-**Service category:**                        \n-**Product capability:** Permissions Management\n-\n-Permissions Management supports third party identity providers (IdP) integration to get more insight of single sign-on data of permissions assigned in cloud environments. With this information, Permissions Management can provide more accurate analytics. By reading role assignments and user data from the IdP side, Permissions Management more effectively calculates permissions granted, and as a result, reads more precise data on permissions creep. \n-\n-For [Okta Identity Provider integration](how-to-configure-okta-as-an-identity-provider.md), an admin needs to configure the API application to give the access to read Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. Permissions Management reads Okta users, groups, and apps via Okta APIs. \n-\n-For [AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) Identity Center integration](how-to-configure-aws-iam.md), an admin can provide Permissions Management access to read user and role access configuration data from the management account by running the CloudFormation template (CFT) in their AWS environment. After successful configuration, Permissions Management can read the data to calculate the analytics.\n-"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: The provided commit history shows extensive changes to the `.openpublishing.redirection.json` file, adding numerous redirection rules for documentation related to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. This indicates a significant restructuring or relocation of content within the documentation set. Additionally, there are modifications to existing documentation files concerning certificate-based authentication and user source of authority configuration, along with the removal of many Permissions Management-related files, suggesting a deprecation or repurposing of that product's documentation.

For more information, see [Sign up for Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2](~/fundamentals/get-started-premium.md).

To start a free 30-day trial, see [Start a trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/trial/get-started-active-directory/). |\n-| You're a Global Administrator in Microsoft Entra ID. |Currently, only Global Administrator accounts can install and configure health agents. .

By using Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC), you can allow other users in your organization to access Microsoft Entra Connect Health. For more information, see [Azure RBAC for Microsoft Entra Connect Health](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).

**Important**: Use a work or school account to install the agents. You can't use a Microsoft account to install the agents. For more information, see [Sign up for Azure as an organization](~/fundamentals/sign-up-organization.md). |\n+| You're either a [Global Administrator](../../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator) or a [Hybrid Identity Administrator](../../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#hybrid-identity-administrator) in Microsoft Entra ID. | By using Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC), you can allow other users in your organization to access Microsoft Entra Connect Health. For more information, see [Azure RBAC for Microsoft Entra Connect Health](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).

For more information, see [Sign up for Azure as an organization](~/fundamentals/sign-up-organization.md). |\n | The Microsoft Entra Connect Health agent is installed on each targeted server. | Health agents must be installed and configured on targeted servers so that they can receive data and provide monitoring and analytics capabilities.

For example, to get data from your Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) infrastructure, you must install the agent on the AD FS server and on the Web Application Proxy server. Similarly, to get data from your on-premises AD Domain Services infrastructure, you must install the agent on the domain controllers. |\n | The Azure service endpoints have outbound connectivity. | During installation and runtime, the agent requires connectivity to Microsoft Entra Connect Health service endpoints. If firewalls block outbound connectivity, add the [outbound connectivity endpoints](how-to-connect-health-agent-install.md#outbound-connectivity-to-azure-service-endpoints) to an allowlist. |\n |Outbound connectivity is based on IP addresses. | For information about firewall filtering based on IP addresses, see [Azure IP ranges](https://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=56519).|\n@@ -113,7 +113,7 @@ The command takes following parameters:\n - `AttributeFiltering`: `$true` (default) if Microsoft Entra Connect isn't syncing the default attribute set and has been customized to use a filtered attribute set. Otherwise, use `$false`.\n - `StagingMode`: `$false` (default) if the Microsoft Entra Connect server is *not* in staging mode. If the server is configured to be in staging mode, use `$true`. You can determine if the server is in staging mode with `(Get-ADSyncScheduler).StagingModeEnabled`.\n \n-When you're prompted for authentication, use the same Global Administrator account (such as `admin@domain.onmicrosoft.com`) that you used to configure Microsoft Entra Connect.\n+When you're prompted for authentication, use the same Global Administrator or Hybrid Identity Administrator account (such as `admin@domain.onmicrosoft.com`) that you used to configure Microsoft Entra Connect.\n \n \n \n@@ -186,7 +186,7 @@ These commands accept `Credential` as a parameter to complete the registration n\n \n - You can capture `Credential` in a PowerShell variable that's passed as a parameter.\n - You can provide any Microsoft Entra identity that has permissions to register the agents, and which does *not* have multifactor authentication enabled.\n-- By default, Global Administrators have permissions to register the agents. You can also allow less-privileged identities to do this step. For more information, see [Azure RBAC](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).\n+- By default, Global Administrators and Hybrid Identity Administrators have permissions to register the agents. You can also allow less-privileged identities to do this step. For more information, see [Azure RBAC](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).\n \n ```powershell\n $cred = Get-Credential" }. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: The changes update the documentation for installing the Microsoft Entra Connect Health agent. The primary modification expands the required administrator roles from just "Global Administrator" to also include "Hybrid Identity Administrator". This provides more flexibility for users in managing access and permissions for installing and configuring the health agents, while still emphasising the use of work or school accounts.

    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,263 @@\n+---\r\n+title: Microsoft Entra ID Protection scenario for mastering risk analysis for effective remediation\r\n+description: Learn about improving risk analysis to identify risky users, discern risk event types, and examine risk levels for access and identity decisions.\r\n+author: gargi-sinha\r\n+manager: martinco\r\n+ms.author: gasinh\r\n+ms.service: entra-id-protection\r\n+ms.topic: concept-article\r\n+ms.date: 10/31/2025\r\n+\r\n+#CustomerIntent: As an administrator, I want to improve my risk analysis, risk assessment, and resulting actions for common risk event types, flagged users, and risk-level patterns.\r\n+---\r\n+# Microsoft Entra ID Protection scenario: Mastering risk analysis for effective remediation\r\n+\r\n+The proof-of-concept (PoC) guidance in this series of articles helps you to learn, deploy, and test Microsoft Entra ID Protection to detect, investigate, and remediate identity-based risks.\r\n+\r\n+An overview of the guidance begins with [Introduction to Microsoft Entra ID Protection proof-of-concept guidance](id-protection-guide-introduction.md).\r\n+\r\n+Detailed guidance continues with these scenarios:\r\n+\r\n+* [Use real-time risk detection to grant access to protected resources](id-protection-guide-detect.md)\r\n+* [Bring identity risk-related telemetry into security investigations](id-protection-guide-investigate.md)\r\n+* [Allow users to self-remediate identity risk for enterprise-managed resources](id-protection-guide-remediate.md)\r\n+\r\n+This article helps identity administrators begin mastering risk analysis for effective remediation with [Azure Monitor Logs](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/data-platform-logs). The following list highlights analysis areas:\r\n+\r\n+* Track risk events across users and sign-ins \r\n+* Correlate anomalies with [Microsoft Entra Conditional Access](../identity/conditional-access/overview.md) policies and sign-in logs \r\n+* Identify potential threat patterns\r\n+  * Enrich investigations and stream telemetry to [Microsoft Defender XDR](/defender-xdr/microsoft-365-defender) and [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview), a security information and event management (SIEM) tool with threat intelligence and a data-lake architecture\r\n+  * You can [search the audit log in Microsoft Defender XDR](/defender-xdr/microsoft-xdr-auditing).\r\n+\r\n+Use the following sections to learn how to manage common risk event types, flagged users, and risk-level patterns with Azure Monitor logs and Microsoft Entra ID Protection.\r\n+\r\n+* [Enable risk analysis with the AADUserRiskEvents table](#enable-risk-analysis-with-the-aaduserriskevents-table)\r\n+* [Ensure prerequisites are met](#ensure-prerequisites-are-met)\r\n+* [Create a Log Analytics workspace](#create-a-log-analytics-workspace)\r\n+* [Identify risky users](#identify-risky-users)\r\n+* [Discern risk event types](#discern-risk-event-types)\r\n+* [Examine risk levels](#examine-risk-levels)\r\n+* [Get started with Azure Monitor Logs reference tables](#get-started-with-azure-monitor-logs-reference-tables)\r\n+\r\n+## Enable risk analysis with the AADUserRiskEvents table \r\n+\r\n+Identity risks grow in speed and complexity every year. You can use risk insights to grasp the volume and details of potential identity attacks and compromises. Enable Azure Monitor Logs reference tables to analyze risk insights with [Microsoft Entra ID Protection](../id-protection/overview-identity-protection.md) that detects, investigates, and remediates identity risks. Risk data goes to access decisions tools, or tools for investigation and correlation. Microsoft Entra ID Protection is continuously updated to help organizations stay ahead of emerging threats. Identity risk management becomes more proactive, scalable, and effective. \r\n+\r\n+With insights, reference tables, and more, you can investigate and remediate identity risks with Conditional Access and construct targeted policies to address your organization's risks.  \r\n+\r\n+Learn more in the [Azure Monitor Logs overview](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/data-platform-logs).\r\n+\r\n+In Microsoft Entra ID Protection, there are four risk tables to query risk events, risky users, and risky [Service Principals](/azure/databricks/admin/users-groups/service-principals). \r\n+\r\n+* AADUserRiskEvents \r\n+* AADRiskyUsers \r\n+* AADServicePrincipalRiskEvents \r\n+* AADRiskyServicePrincipals \r\n+\r\n+In this article, the focus is the **AADUserRiskEvents** table. To understand more about discerning risks to your organization, see the following video. \r\n+\r\n+**Mastering risk analysis with Microsoft Entra ID Protection** \r\n+\r\n+   > [!VIDEO abb7d7fe-4155-4ee1-bcce-afa027d22f8d]\r\n+\r\n+## Ensure prerequisites are met\r\n+\r\n+To use Azure Monitor, ensure the following prerequisites are met. \r\n+\r\n+* A Microsoft Entra ID P2 Premium license\r\n+  * See [Microsoft Entra plans and pricing](https://www.microsoft.com/security/business/microsoft-entra-pricing?msockid=3c61c9beef5963ba2f03dc9cee156239)\r\n+* An Azure account with an active subscription\r\n+  * Learn about [Azure accounts](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/purchase-options/azure-account/)\r\n+* Microsoft.OperationalInsights/workspaces/write permissions to the resource group for the Log Analytics workspace\r\n+  * Learn about the **Log Analytics Contributor** role in [manage access to Log Analytics workspaces](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/manage-access)\r\n+\r\n+## Create a Log Analytics workspace\r\n+\r\n+A Log Analytics workspace is a data store to collect log data types from Azure and non-Azure resources and applications. We recommend you send all log data to one Log Analytics workspace.\r\n+\r\n+1. [Create a Log Analytics workspace](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/quick-create-workspace).\r\n+2. To incorporate the data you want to analyze, add diagnostics settings. See the following list.\r\n+\r\n+* AuditLogs\r\n+* SignInLogs\r\n+* NonInteractiveUserSignInLogs\r\n+* ServicePrincipalSignInLogs\r\n+* ManagedIdentitySignInLogs\r\n+* RiskyUsers\r\n+* UserRiskEvents\r\n+* RiskyServicePrincipals\r\n+* ServicePrincipalRiskEvents\r\n+\r\n+3. To view the Queries hub, got to the Log Analytics workspace.\r\n+4. Select **Logs**.\r\n+5. Search for **Risk**.\r\n+6. Locate the **Recent user risk events query**.\r\n+7. Select **Run**.\r\n+8. From the dropdown, change **Simple mode** to Kusto Query Language mode (**KQL mode**).\r\n+\r\n+Screenshot of the **KQL mode** option.\r\n+\r\n+   ![Screenshot of the KQL-mode option in the dropdown menu.](./media/id-protection-guide-analyze/kql-mode.png)\r\n+\r\n+## Identify risky users\r\n+\r\n+This section and the following sections illustrate how to analyze risk with Azure Monitor. Risk users have one or more risky sign-ins, or other risky actions\r\n+\r\n+1. Run the query to summarize the count by **UserDisplayName**.\r\n+2. Add a time range in **DetectedDateTime < ago()**.  \r\n+\r\n+In the following example query, **30d** is the date range. \r\n+\r\n+```kusto\r\n+// Recent user risk events \r\n+// Gets list of the top 100 active user risk events. \r\n+AADUserRiskEvents \r\n+| where DetectedDateTime > ago(30d) \r\n+| where RiskState == \"atRisk\" \r\n+| take 100 \r\n+| summarize count()by UserDisplayName \r\n+```\r\n+\r\n+Use the previous query to identify common user patterns, such as service accounts, or small user subsets generating large amounts of risk. In the following screenshot, there are risky users. One generates more risk events than the others. For this scenario, you can block the user, or require a secure password change. \r\n+\r\n+   ![Screenshot of risky user data from the query.](./media/id-protection-guide-analyze/risky-users.png)\r\n+\r\n+## Discern risk event types\r\n+\r\n+Risk even types include unfamiliar sign-in, unusual tokens, and unlikely travel are examples. After you determine user patterns, review detections and summarize them by the risk event type.  \r\n+\r\n+1. Use the **AADUserRiskEvents** table.\r\n+2. Summarize with **RiskEventType**. \r\n+\r\n+**Example query**\r\n+```kusto\r\n+// Recent user risk events \r\n+// Gets list of the top 100 active user risk events. \r\n+AADUserRiskEvents \r\n+| where DetectedDateTime > ago(30d) \r\n+| where RiskState == \"atRisk\" \r\n+| take 100  \r\n+| summarize count()by RiskEventType \r\n+```\r\n+\r\n+While reviewing risk types, pay attention to large volumes. In the following screenshot, there are flagged risk events, most are related to:\r\n+\r\n+* **UnfamiliarFeatures** - Detect unfamiliar sign-in properties for a user\r\n+  * Enforce session controls such as sign-in frequency, application restrictions, and persistent browser controls\r\n+* **AnomalousToken** - Set up Conditional Access policies to require password reset and perform multifactor authentication (MFA)\r\n+  * Block access for high-risk sign-ins\r\n+* **UnlikelyTravel** - Add named locations as trusted IPs\r\n+  * Enable trusted locations for users that travel frequently\r\n+\r\n+See the following screenshot of results from the active-user risk events query.\r\n+\r\n+   ![Screenshot of the results from the active-user risk events query.](./media/id-protection-guide-analyze/risk-events.png)\r\n+\r\n+## Examine risk levels\r\n+\r\n+Risk-level totals enable effective decision making. Examine the **AADUserRiskEvents** table to review low-, medium-, and high-risk levels. Summarize risk events by level and analyze risk level totals. \r\n+\r\n+**Example query**\r\n+```kusto\r\n+// Recent user risk events \r\n+// Gets list of the top 100 active user risk events. \r\n+AADUserRiskEvents \r\n+| where DetectedDateTime > ago(30d) \r\n+| where RiskState == \"atRisk\" \r\n+| take 100 \r\n+| summarize count()by RiskLevel  \r\n+```\r\n+\r\n+In the following screenshot, three detections are high-risk. We recommend a minimum-baseline Conditional Access policy that requires secure password change, or that blocks high-risk users. \r\n+\r\n+   ![Screenshot of query results that show three high-risk users.](./media/id-protection-guide-analyze/three-high.png)\r\n+\r\n+Learn more about access control decisions: [What is Conditional Access?](/azure/data-explorer/security-conditional-access)\r\n+\r\n+## Get started with Azure Monitor Logs reference tables\r\n+\r\n+To help you get started, see and learn more about Azure Monitor Log reference tables for Microsoft Entra ID Protection. The following links go to a list of tables by table name. Use logs generated by identity protection for user risk events, risky users, Service Principal risk events, risky Service Principals, and more.\r\n+\r\n+* [AADUserRiskEvents](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aaduserriskevents)\r\n+* [AADRiskyUsers](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aadriskyusers)\r\n+* [AADServicePrincipalRiskEvents](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aadserviceprincipalriskevents)\r\n+* [AADRiskyServicePrincipals](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aadriskyserviceprincipals)\r\n+\r\n+## Next steps\r\n+\r\n+* [Introduction to Microsoft Entra ID Protection proof-of-concept guidance](id-protection-guide-introduction.md)\r\n+* [Use real-time risk detection to grant access to protected resources](id-protection-guide-detect.md)\r\n+* Master risk analysis for effective remediation\r\n+* [Bring identity risk-related telemetry into security investigations](id-protection-guide-investigate.md)\r\n+* [Allow users to self-remediate identity risk for enterprise-managed resources](id-protection-guide-remediate.md)  \r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r\n+\r"

    "patch": "@@ -6,20 +6,21 @@ manager: martinco\n ms.author: gasinh\n ms.service: entra-id-protection\n ms.topic: concept-article\n-ms.date: 08/22/2025\n+ms.date: 10/31/2025\n \n #CustomerIntent: As an IT administrator, I want to use Microsoft Entra ID Protection to identify and remediate identity risks so that I can protect users that access enterprise-managed resources.\n ---\n-# Microsoft Entra ID Protection scenario: user identity risk self-remediation for enterprise-managed resources\n+# Microsoft Entra ID Protection scenario: User identity risk self-remediation for enterprise-managed resources\n \n The proof-of-concept (PoC) guidance in this series of articles helps you to learn, deploy, and test Microsoft Entra ID Protection to detect, investigate, and remediate identity-based risks.\n \n An overview of the guidance begins with [Introduction to Microsoft Entra ID Protection proof-of-concept guidance](id-protection-guide-introduction.md).\n \n Detailed guidance continues with these scenarios:\n \n-- [Use real-time risk detection to grant access to protected resources](id-protection-guide-detect.md)\n-- [Bring identity risk-related telemetry into security investigations](id-protection-guide-investigate.md)\n+* [Use real-time risk detection to grant access to protected resources](id-protection-guide-detect.md)\n+* [Master risk analysis for effective remediation](id-protection-guide-analyze.md)\n+* [Bring identity risk-related telemetry into security investigations](id-protection-guide-investigate.md)\n \n This article helps administrators to identify and remediate identity risks for users accessing enterprise-managed resources, including Microsoft 365. Use real-time and offline risk detections to evaluate sign-ins and user behavior. Apply automated responses such as multifactor authentication (MFA), password resets, or block access based on risk levels. A new document, `id-protection-guide-analyze.md`, has been added, detailing how to master risk analysis for effective remediation using Microsoft Entra ID Protection and Azure Monitor Logs. This includes guidance on tracking risk events, discerning risk types, and examining risk levels.

The existing documents `id-protection-guide-detect.md`, `id-protection-guide-introduction.md`, `id-protection-guide-investigate.md`, and `id-protection-guide-remediate.md` have been updated to include a link to the new analysis guide, enhancing the overall structure and discoverability of the Microsoft Entra ID Protection proof-of-concept guidance series.

Additionally, several image files have been added to support the new `id-protection-guide-analyze.md` document, and the `toc.yml` file has been updated to reflect the inclusion of the new article. The `whats-new.md` document has also been updated with an announcement regarding a change to the MFA session revocation functionality.
